column1: Please note that in this “Long” version of the Student Opportunity Bulletin, all
opportunities in each category are included.
For the list of only the New and Deadline Approaching opportunities in each category,
you may click & open the “Short” version of the Student Opportunity document you
(Download this entire PDF document in order to use the following links to jump to
This weekly bulletin will inform students, parents, and staff about internships,
academic programs, jobs, leadership & community service initiatives, along with
other student opportunities in a variety of fields. Please carefully note deadlines, age
requirements, and other pre-requisites for participation.
For ease of use, these newsletters are organized by different categories, such as
Academic Programs, Business Internships & Jobs, STEM Opportunities, Community
These various opportunities utilize different formats. Some are in-person, some
remote, and some will involve a hybrid arrangement. Check each program for their
specific format and schedule. Students should consider applying to any that match
their interests and talents. Some program deadlines are fast approaching – please
Some highlighted programs in the categories below (often with approaching
EVENTS: There are several free Hackathons coming up in the next few weeks –
most are open to any interested student, and no prior expertise is required – these are
generally fun & educational ways for students to learn more about this field.
Also, the NYU Tandon School of Engineering in Brooklyn is offering a three-day
Games & Cybersecurity Conference in early November; this free event is open to
all students. And there is a STEM College Fair at the New York Hall of SDcience in
Corona on October 10th – all are welcome.
BUSINESS: Harvard University students welcome all female high schoolers with an
interest in business & entrepreneurship to participate in their BOLD Conference in
November. There are low-cost in-person and virtual options, with financial aid
LEADERSHIP/GOVERNMENT: There are numerous leadership and civic
participation programs available over the next few months – some have fast-
approaching deadlines, so interested students should check them out ASAP!
STEM: The Ace Mentor program welcomes all students to participate in their year-
long engineering/architecture collaboration with the Port Authority of NY/NJ.
Students work with PA professionals on a real project, in-person, at their offices near
Stuyvesant. Meetings begin in early November and take place after school on
Tuesdays - all are welcome to apply.
The Science Alliance from the American Museum of Natural History offers an eight-
week after-school course on entomology/insect diversity & human health,
beginning on 10/10. All students may apply; the cost is $1,000 but financial aid may
And The Perry Initiative is offering another free, in-person medical/orthopedics
event on November 9th; it is open to 10th graders and older, and will be held at
Columbia University; the application deadline is 10/22.
Questions, suggestions, and information about other opportunities are always
welcome and appreciated, and may be sent to Internship/Opportunity Coordinator
Harvey Blumm at: hblumm@stuy.edu - we will share your helpful information with
“Luna Hackathon, organized by Hack Club, a worldwide organization dedicated to
supporting teens interested in computer science, is a day-long programming marathon
where students team up to attend workshops, code new projects, learn basic
programming skills, and have fun. Luna Hackathon invites all teenagers who identify
as girls or gender-nonconforming youth to attend the event for 12 hours of creating,
Eligible: All students who identify as a girl, non-binary, or gender-nonconforming
Location: Civic Hall; 124 E 14th St, Manhattan
New: Event Approaching: NYC STEM College Fair
“We are partnering with 20 colleges, universities, and other youth-serving
organizations to bring high school and college-bound students a range of helpful
resources! We'll have staffed tables with college and career readiness resources, as
well as other educational and STEAM information in higher learning. Additionally,
this is an exciting opportunity for students to learn more about FAFSA, and get tips on
how to showcase their STEM experiences, achievements, and passions in the college
Kings Bay Brooklyn Public Library CRAFTIVISM: Teen Crafts and Activism for
“Join authors Ali Terese and Rachel E. Gross for an afternoon of arts & crafts and
● Create crafts, such as friendship bracelets, sculptures, and posters.
● Get your questions about periods, menstrual health, and puberty answered.”
Location: Kings Bay Library, 3650 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn
New: NYU/Tandon Cybersecurity Games & Conference Event (CSAW’24)
"CSAW, open to all students, is the most comprehensive student-run cyber security
event in the world, featuring 7 cyber competitions, workshops, and industry events.
Final events are hosted by 5 global academic centers. "
Location: NYU Tandon, Center for Cybersecurity, 370 Jay St, Brooklyn
“Intergenerational Change Initiative (ICI) launched the Youth Ask Youth (YAY)
Census, gathering responses from youth across five boroughs about their
experiences related to learning, community, COVID-19, policing and more. We
submit this data to major stakeholders like the Department of Youth and Community
Development, the Department of Education, and the Deputy Mayor’s office. You can
raise your voice, be heard... and earn a chance to win a $25 gift card, just by taking
Many universities offer free or very low-cost one or two-day Splash programs for high
school students to take classes on various subjects taught by their current college
students. These can be virtual, in-person, or hybrid in format. Here is a link for a
number of upcoming events, including those at Cornell, MIT, Johns Hopkins,
“Splash is a one-day program of classes taught by Yale students on a diverse range of
subjects, such as Into the Future: How "Spider-Verse" Forced Animation to Evolve,
Introduction to Improv Comedy, Elementary Particle Physics, Ethics Meets Self-
Driving Cars: Philosophy, Technology and More, Kafka and Monty Python, The
Syrian Refugee Crisis, Feminism in the Beyonce Era, and more.”
Location: Yale Campus (451 College St, New Haven, CT)
“Our hackathon is an exciting opportunity for high school students to develop
innovative solutions within three key pathways: Sustainability, Health & Wellness,
and Education & Accessibility. The event will begin offline on Monday, September
30th, allowing participants to start their projects, and culminate in an in-person event
on October 4th. We will provide mentorship from industry experts, hands-on
workshops, and exciting prizes for the winning teams. On the day of the event, we will
have volunteers to help students finish up their projects (for those who started earlier)
or assist those just getting started.
Students can register and find more information about the hackathon by visiting our
website: https://divergentteams.org/hackathon/ . Teams can consist of up to four
members. If you don't have a team, don't worry! Sign up individually, and we'll match
you with other participants to form a team. Even if you're unable to work on your
project during the week, you can still join us. There will be plenty of time on October
4th to create and submit your project.”
Location: Hybrid: Culminating event at Microsoft Offices at 11 Times Square,
“Luna Hackathon, organized by Hack Club, a worldwide organization dedicated to
supporting teens interested in computer science, is a day-long programming marathon
where students team up to attend workshops, code new projects, learn basic
programming skills, and have fun. Luna Hackathon invites all teenagers who identify
as girls or gender-nonconforming youth to attend the event for 12 hours of creating,
Eligible: All students who identify as a girl, non-binary, or gender-nonconforming
Location: Civic Hall; 124 E 14th St, Manhattan
Endless Frontiers Lab Youth Ambassador Program
“Endless Frontier Labs invites high school students interested in the intersections of
entrepreneurship, technology, and/or science-based innovation to apply for our 2023-
2024 Young Ambassadors cohort! During the EFL Young Ambassadors experience,
students will have the opportunity to shadow world-renowned scientists, CEOs, and
business leaders and observe their meetings with startup founders in the Endless
Students will be admitted on a rolling basis. If admitted, students will attend at least
one (1) EFL Meeting Day. The EFL program will be operating in a hybrid model this
If you have any questions, please contact info@endlessfrontierlabs.com
Eligible: All students; focus on under-represented/low income, but all may apply
Locations: NYU Stern (50 W 4th St, Manhattan) or Virtual
Event Approaching: Virtual NACAC National College Fairs
“Free and open to the public, National College Fairs are the perfect place to kick off
your college search. Admission representatives from schools across the country are all
gathered in one place. Their goal: To encourage you to learn more about their
institutions, and help you sort through the qualities you’re looking for in a college.
Use your visit to explore your options, ask questions, and gather information.”
Events Approaching: Cybersecurity Career Awareness Week
“All students are welcome to learn about topics and careers in this innovative &
important field of cybersecurity. A variety of events and competitions will be offered
Event Approaching: Open House New York (OHNY) Weekend
“OHNY Weekend is an annual festival that opens hundreds of noteworthy or
significant places across the five boroughs for three days of in-person and virtual
tours, talks, and special activities. It is a free celebration of “the power of place,”
fostering discovery and delight for all New Yorkers and deepening the public’s
understanding of how design can strengthen communities and improve quality of
Location: Hybrid (virtual and in-person content available)
“Columbia Climate School Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory welcomes aspiring
young scientists and science enthusiasts to come enjoy Lamont-Doherty’s Open
House. You will tour a lab, participate in hands-on earth science demonstrations, and
learn from world-renowned researchers about their latest discoveries. If you are
attending Open House from New York City, free shuttle buses are provided between
Columbia University's Morningside Heights campus in Manhattan and the Lamont-
“Students from the tri-state area are invited to attend this FREE college fair to learn
more about applying to architecture school. Representatives from over 30 schools
nationwide will be on-hand at the Center for Architecture to meet with students and
Location: Center for Architecture (536 LaGuardia Place, Manhattan)
Teens Art Connection - Pizza and a Movie (PaaM)
“As a PaaM teen you will eat delicious pizza on us and decide what movie to watch
with a vote. Each month PaaM hosts present a new theme with a menu of 3 mystery
movies. Movie titles aren’t revealed until movie night. Connect with other NYC teens,
learn behind the scenes movie facts and share your reactions in real- time. Post movie,
join the talk-back to explore themes in the movie.”
Eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old
Dates: November 1, December 6, January 3, February 7, and more from 5-8 pm
Location: 53rd Street Library, 18 West 53rd Street, Manhattan
Queens Public Library College Readiness Workshops
“This September, QPL is offering a robust series of programs to help students prepare
for the upcoming college admissions cycle. Whether you’re getting ready to apply to
college this fall, or just becoming curious about the college application process, we
are here to support you.” Explore our upcoming offerings below, and please send your
For students interested in learning more about the Macaulay experience, Macaulay
hosts information sessions for prospective students about admission requirements, key
dates, essay tips, the Macaulay application, information from Macaulay students, and
Several NYC college campuses offer free or low-cost STEP (Science & Technology
Entry Program) STEM courses, and are available to all students from lower-income
or under-represented backgrounds. They cover different STEM topics and often
include SAT prep. Here is a link to some that are still available:
Cooper Union STEM Saturdays Engineering & Design Classes
“Whether redesigning a monument to share untold stories or creating a place for
people to gather and celebrate, students will learn skills from Civil, Mechanical and
Electrical Engineering. The skills will range from computer aided design to data
analysis to electrical circuit design. Each session ends with a celebration and student
showcase highlighting progress made towards developing skills and addressing
community needs. Priority is given to students with no design or engineering
experience.” Students will be provided materials, lunch and snacks, and MetroCard.
Eligible: Current 9th, 10th, and 11th grade students who are low or middle income; All
are welcome to apply - priority is given to students that identify with a group
Dates: October to February, depending on the program
Yale Young Global Scholars Summer Program
YYGS invites students to several different ten-day sessions in which they can
“experience life as a university student at Yale while attending an academic session of
their choosing.” A variety of classes are available, including ‘Innovations in Science
& Technology’ ‘Literature, Philosophy & Culture,” Solving Global Challenges,’ and
others. Information webinars on the program are scheduled from early October to
December and range from topics such as Admissions Advice to the Session
Eligible: All Sophomores & Juniors 16 and older by July 20, 2025
Dates: Session I (June 22 – July 4) OR Session II (July 6 – 18) OR Session III (July
Application Deadline: October 20 (Early Action) or January 10, 2025 (Regular
Columbia University Spring Academic Year Weekend Remote Courses
All students are invited to apply for weekend classes in a wide variety of fields,
including Creative Writing, Psychology, Science, Medicine, and more.
Cost: $2,810 per course (no financial aid offered)
Harvard Student Agencies Weekend Junior Academies
“The Academies @HOME offers weekend programs curated by Harvard faculty and
taught by undergraduates to help students explore a career path of their choosing:
business, business consulting, coding, pre-law, pre-med, or politics. They run for two
consecutive weekends for four hours each day, totaling out to 16 hours of guided
Application Deadline: Rolling Basis (applications are due at least one week before
“Are you interested in studying defining moments in our history while relating those
moments to the important issues we face as a nation today? This summer, the National
History Academy (NHA) offers a four-week program focused on voting rights, the
Electoral College, and more. Participants will closely examine cases covering
different aspects of American democracy. Each case includes a decision point
followed by relevant background information that the original decision-maker would
Eligible: Rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors
For information about obtaining Working Papers at Stuyvesant, check this link:
New: NYU SPS Career Pathways Bridge Program
“NYU SPS Division of Applied Undergraduate Studies (DAUS) offers low- or no-
cost associate degree programs in Business, Information Systems Management, and
Liberal Arts, that emphasize real-world learning experiences and equip students with
the essential skills needed for today’s workforce. The Bridge Program provides a
direct pathway into the NYU SPS associate degree program, a full scholarship, and
academic assistance and career readiness during the fall semester. The Bridge
Program and Bridge Scholarship also include paid internship opportunities, early
college credit, academic advising, career coaching, and peer mentoring, along with
cohort-style learning, career exploration, skill-building activities, meal plans, monthly
Metrocards, and stipends for course materials and needs.”
Eligible: Current Seniors who are eligible for Pell and TAP
Dates: Fall 2025 (Informational Events: October 10, November 9, November 20)
Location: Hybrid; In-Person at New York University
Events Today & Approaching: NYC Exploring Careers Program
“Students interested in learning about different career paths can join the NYC
Exploring program. It uses in-person & virtual weekly or bi-weekly after-school
sessions to introduce students to a wide variety of careers. List of programs scheduled
   Kings County District Attorney’s Office (Law & Government) Thursdays at 4:30-6:00pm 10/10, 10/24, 11/7,
   Queens County District Attorney’s Office (Law & Government) Tuesdays at 4:30-6:00pm 10/15, 10/29, 11/12,
   Lenox Health Greenwich Village (Medicine/Nursing) Thursdays at 4:30-6:00pm 10/17, 11/21, 12/19, 1/16,
   Carver Federal Savings Bank (Finance/Accounting/Business) Wednesdays at 4:30-6:00pm 11/6, 11/13
Deadline Approaching: Futures and Options Internship Program
“The Futures and Options Internship Program provides New York City high school
students with critical work-readiness training and the opportunity to gain firsthand
work experience as interns with a dynamic range of business partners. Futures and
Options interns work for a total of 60-100 hours in paid, mentored internships that
best match their skills and interests.”
Eligible: Students who are at least 16 years old and have working papers
Location: Varies depending on student and business partner needs
Deadline Approaching: Brooklyn Museum Paid Apprentice Program
“In this paid internship, New York City teens immerse themselves in art and art
history, and learn about museum education while creating their own lessons for
audiences of all ages. Get paid $16 per hour. Second-year Museum Apprentices serve
as leaders in the program and are paid $17 per hour. Work up to 180 hours for the
year! Metrocards will be provided to support weekend and summer work.” Students
will need to submit an application and a letter of recommendation.
Eligible: All students who are at least 14 years old
Dates: November through August 2025 (Thursday afternoons from 5:00 – 7 :00pm
with occasional Friday and weekend events)
Location: Brooklyn Museum (200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn)
Deadline Approaching: Department of Housing Preservation and Development
“HPD is at the forefront of solving the City's housing crisis and protecting renters. Our
team oversees all public relations for HPD and is responsible for promoting agency
initiatives, programs, and accomplishments. As an intern, students gain real, hands-on
experience and contribute to meaningful projects that support our mission to address
the housing crisis and serve New Yorkers. The available positions are: Social Media
and Digital Intern, Press Intern, Public Engagement Intern, and Event and Executive
Intern. Send your resume & cover letter with the preferred role and dates to Ilana
“Young Founders Lab is a selective start-up bootcamp for ambitious high school
students. In the program, you work under the guidance of mentors from places like
Google, Microsoft, and Meta to build your own revenue generating start-ups. Young
Founders Lab is a real-world start-up bootcamp based on incubators such as the Y-
Combinator. You have the option to work individually or in groups.”
Dates: December 21 - January 5 (12:00pm - 3:00pm) or 12-week individual plan
“StandOut Connect is a program that matches high school students with companies
founded by top university alumni. Over the course of the program, students will be
taught how to recruit for and succeed in internships by alumni from top ten
universities who have broken into fields such as finance, venture capital, and Big
Tech. Then they will complete a two-month internship at an industry-leading company
in their area of interest. Students will leave the program having spearheaded a project
at their company match, with many receiving return offers to continue part-time into
Eligible: All students who are at least 15 years old
Student Election Day Poll Worker Jobs
Students (U.S. citizens) 17 and older may apply to become paid poll workers at NYC
voting sites on the upcoming elections on November 5th. Students will be paid for that
day and they will also be paid for a half-day weekend training session (paid only if
they subsequently work on election day). Interested students may contact Harvey
Blumm at hblumm@stuy.edu for more information.
Eligible: All students 17 and older by November 5 who are U.S. citizens
Harvard Undergraduate Women in Business Oriented Leadership Development
"This is an event for high school women leaders who are pursuing empowerment and
knowledge from inspirational businesswomen. The ‘Business Oriented Leadership
Development’ (BOLD) conference is designed to help the next generation of women
leaders obtain skills and guidance toward their future in business. Participants will
learn about business and engage with current Harvard business majors and local
Cost: $135.23 (in-person cost on the Harvard campus) & $44.52 (virtual cost)
“The Robert Zur fall intern program is an opportunity for high school interns
interested in the fashion industry. It offers a remarkable chance to dive headfirst into
the world of fashion and gain invaluable hands-on experience in a professional
environment. By participating in this program (unpaid), interns will have the
opportunity to acquire knowledge and skills that are highly sought after in the
Different positions include Data Science Analytics, E-Commerce Interns, Digital
Marketing Specialist, and Content Creator. Internships are unpaid - You will obtain a
Certificate of Completion upon completion of internship.”
“This program helps you discover the right business area for you. You will experience
Ivy League faculty through one of the nation’s top business schools and acquire the
tools you need for your future from expert practitioners. All programs are 100 percent
online, allowing you to study at your own pace. You’ll be guided by mentors and
collaborate with motivated peers from around the globe.
You will also complete a final project and receive a certificate of participation from
Columbia Business School. Currently available programs are The Business of Luxury,
The Business of Sports, The Business of TV and Film: An Insider's Look, and The
Business of Hospitality: Travel and Dining.”
New York Women in Business Coalition
“Kick off the school year with The NYC Women In Business Coalition! We invite
all new and returning members to join us for their events of the fall season. Although
membership is not required for this event, you will have an opportunity to join our
Eligible: All NYC high school young women
InvestIn Career Opportunities, Podcasts, & Career Guide
“Learn directly from some of the world's best professionals - doctors, lawyers,
engineers, investment bankers and more - through a series of live, interactive
simulations which provide tailor-made professional experiences to ages 12-18.”
Available careers: Medicine, Engineering, Investment Banking, Law, Psychology,
Architecture, Art, Dentistry, Entrepreneurship, Fashion, Filmmaking, Forensic
Science, International Development, Journalism, Politics, Software Engineering, Vet,
Location: Virtual or in-person in London, England
Harvard Student Agencies Weekend Junior Academies
“The Academies @HOME offers weekend programs curated by Harvard faculty and
taught by undergraduates to help students explore a career path of their choosing:
business, business consulting, coding, pre-law, pre-med, or politics. They run for two
consecutive weekends for four hours each day, totaling out to 16 hours of guided
Application Deadline: Rolling Basis (applications are due at least one week before
“CareerInfo is a mobile app developed by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics that
provides in-depth data and information about available careers. You can browse by
job titles, groups, or keywords to learn about: Median pay, typical work
environments, required skills and experience, and more.”
New: St. John’s Bread and Life
“Bread and Life works to ensure that communities have access to healthy, nutritious
food. Tasks for volunteers include Pantry Bag Packer, Produce Packing, Maintenance
Volunteering at Bread & Life allows individuals to directly combat food insecurity, a
pressing societal issue, and make an immediate impact on the lives of those in need.
All volunteers under 18 must be accompanied by an adult.
Dates: Mondays to Thursdays, 8:00am – 2:00pm (convenient for days with no school
General List of Local Volunteer Opportunities:
For a list of some food programs that help hungry New Yorkers, click this link:
Most NYC hospitals welcome high school student helpers. Age requirements and time
commitments vary, so contact locations of interest for more specific information.
For a list of some other hospital volunteer opportunities, check this link:
“Join a remarkable group of students in learning how to make meaningful connections
with peers, mentors, and business leaders, all while supporting St. Jude patients and
families. During a six-month period, members will have an opportunity to exercise
their leadership skills while raising funds and awareness for the kids of St. Jude. Like-
minded teens will follow a mentor, participate in leadership development, shared
Asian Americans for Equality Volunteer Program
“Are you looking to make a difference in your community? If so, joining the AAFE
team as a volunteer is a great way to contribute in a meaningful way. As the impacts
of the pandemic and the rise in AAPI hate continue to be felt in Chinatown, Flushing,
Jackson Heights, Elmhurst, and beyond, AAFE has organized many mutual aid events
to help provide food, clothing, social services, and housing assistance to the most
vulnerable community members in the neighborhoods we serve. On an ongoing basis,
we need volunteers to help set up and run our food pantries and other giveaways, help
with Chinese and Spanish translation, provide professional services, and more.”
“MyVote Project is a new, nonpartisan, voter education website. High school students
can get involved in outreach, making content for the website, social media
management, etc. This is a way for students to gain official community service hours
“You're not just a part of your city, you're shaping its future. Now's your chance to get
involved, have fun, and make a difference! In partnership with NYC Public Schools,
we bring you hundreds of opportunities to engage in your community. Ready to join?
Register and sign up for a volunteer project near you.”
For a general list of programs (mostly free) that provide college admissions
information and support to seniors and students from other grades, check this link:
The Opportunity Hub - College Application Workshop Series
“We invite your students and program participants to join us for a series of free virtual
college admissions workshops. These workshops will provide valuable insights and
strategies to help you navigate the college application process. The series will have
workshops like Crafting Your College List, Navigating College Admissions,
Unleashing Your College Essay, and Dollars & Degrees: Your Guide to Educational
“Thrive Scholars is not just an academic program—it's a transformational experience.
We provide high-achieving young people the opportunities they need to thrive at top
colleges and in meaningful careers, all at no cost to the students. We’re looking for
high-achieving, underrepresented students, including students of color from under-
resourced communities, who excel academically, demonstrate leadership, and are
passionate for attending a top university and pursuing a high-trajectory career. Thrive
Scholars provides the OnRamp, 6-Year, and Thrive Academics programs.”
Eligible: Sophomores and Juniors who identify as underrepresented students
Events Approaching: CACNY Senior Series Program
“Senior Series is a 3-month college access program intended to support high school
seniors through various aspects of the college application process. Senior Series
features both in-person and virtual workshops on topics including college choice,
applications, admissions, and success. During our workshop sessions, we guide
students through navigating the Common App, and SUNY and CUNY application
portals. In addition, we offer office hours, which serve as advisory sessions where
students receive one on one support for writing college essays and FAFSA
completion. Participants who successfully complete all outlined milestones are
eligible to receive up to a $500 stipend.”F
Location: Hybrid; In-Person at 185 Broadway 2nd Floor, Brooklyn 11211
These in-person and online sessions provide helpful information about different State
University of New York (SUNY) campuses, financial aid, FAFSA completion, special
Location: Virtual and in-person (116 East 55th St, Manhattan) options available
“Learn about everything college and college admissions right from the experts –
admissions counselors from Coalition schools. Coalition For College offers a series of
workshops that focus on topics on applying to colleges such as College Affordability
& Scholarships, The CSS Profile, College Applications, and Completing the FAFSA.”
Queens Public Library College Readiness Workshops
“This September, QPL is offering a robust series of programs to help students prepare
for the upcoming college admissions cycle. Whether you’re getting ready to apply to
college this fall, or just becoming curious about the college application process, we
are here to support you.” Explore our upcoming offerings below, and please send your
For students interested in learning more about the Macaulay experience, Macaulay
hosts information sessions for prospective students about admission requirements, key
dates, essay tips, the Macaulay application, information from Macaulay students, and
“The NYC Office of School Wellness Programs is launching Student Wellness
Advocates, an opportunity for students in grades 9-12 to join a citywide youth
leadership group. Student Wellness Advocates will implement NYCPS’ vision for
student wellness, physical and health education, physical activity, school food,
nutrition, and climate sustainability. Learn more at the links below; complete the
Youth Leadership Council Online Application and be sure to check the NYC Public
Schools/Students Wellness Advocates box to become a Student Wellness Advocate.
Cost: Free –stipends will be given to participants
New: Council on International Exchange (CIEE) Study Abroad Programs Early
“CIEE offers a variety of programs for students to explore another culture and
language in over 30 different countries. Through their Summer Abroad, High School
Abroad, and Gap Year Abroad opportunities, students can “immerse themselves in a
new language and culture”. Enter application by November 1 for a chance to fly free.
Deadline Extended/ Approaching: Youth Action Institute
“YAI is a paid fellowship for LGBTQ+ youth, ages 16-21, who are residents of New
York City. We train young folks in social justice foundations, policy and systems
analysis, research skills, and advocacy. With those skills, they then join ongoing
research and advocacy efforts to improve outcomes for queer and trans youth in NYC.
Youth are paid for their time, including their training time; they are expected to attend
4 hours of group sessions and 1 hour of individual coaching each week.”
Eligible: All LGBTQ+ students 16 and older
New: United States Senate Youth Program
“The United States Senate Youth Program, established in 1962 by U.S. Senate
Resolution, is a unique educational experience for outstanding high school students
interested in pursuing careers in public service. Two student leaders from each state,
the District of Columbia and the Department of Defense Education Activity will spend
a week in Washington experiencing their national government in action.” Recipients
will also be granted a $10,000 scholarship.
Eligible: Students in grades 11-12 who show demonstrated leadership by serving in
elected or appointed positions in which they are actively representing or previously
represented a constituency in organizations related to student government, education,
public affairs and community service. Applicants will be nominated by their school –
interested students should contact Harvey Blum to learn more.
Cost: Free (Transportation, food, and housing provided)
New: Congress Bundestag Youth Exchange Program (CBYX)
“CBYX is a full scholarship exchange program that offers young Americans the
opportunity to live with a German host family and attend high school in Germany for
a year. CBYX aims to foster cultural understanding and diplomacy while also
promoting the German and English languages. Participants are also encouraged to
learn about the political systems of their host country. Become fluent in German, learn
about another culture, and expand your horizons.”
Eligible: Students who are between the ages of 15 and 18.5 and U.S. citizens
Office of Energy & Sustainability Youth Leadership Council
“NYCPS Sustainability drives change in all NYC schools by making school buildings
more energy, waste, and water efficient and by creating more opportunities for
students to access green space, learn about the environment and climate change, and
become empowered to take action. The NYCPS Sustainability YLC encourages
diverse high school students to increase inclusive and impactful sustainability and
climate action across NYC schools and communities.
This year, the YLC will focus on planning the NYCPS Youth Climate Summit and
supporting Climate Action Days in all schools in NYC. ”
Dates: Monthly on Thursdays (4:30pm-6:30pm), October – June 2025
Events Approaching: UA3 X Toastmasters Public Speaking Workshop
“Toastmasters is a safe space for youth to develop their public speaking skills and
learn the importance of communication. They can listen to and voice their different
perspectives, meet new people, make connections, and earn a certificate (once
completed). This free workshop series allows high school students to develop
Deadline Approaching: Career and College Youth Internship Program
“The Riverdale Neighborhood House Career & College Youth Internship Program is a
stipend-based paid internship. If you are a high school student looking to develop job
skills, explore careers and colleges, and gain experiences that will boost your resume
and/or college application, you are encouraged to apply. Selected interns will receive
individualized strategies and support for their post-secondary goals, as well as
participate in various activities to enhance their experience including career club,

“Reel Works’ free after-school programs pair teens with professional filmmaker-
mentors to create original short documentaries, narrative, and experimental films that

“The Doc Lab is our introductory documentary filmmaking workshop. High school
students learn how to tell a story using filmmaking and are paired 1:1 with
professional filmmaker mentors to plan, shoot, edit, and present a short personal film
about their lives and communities. This is a free introductory course to documentary
filmmaking and no previous filmmaking experience is necessary.”
Location: Reel Works Teen Filmmaking; 540 President Street, Brooklyn
“The Narrative Lab is designed for experienced young filmmakers in high school to
develop their ideas into short fiction films. The Narrative Lab focuses on
screenwriting, advanced camera and lighting, casting and directing actors, producing,
and post-production of short 7-10 minute films. Students are paired 1:1 with
professional mentors whom they will meet with weekly throughout the program.”
Location: Reel Works Teen Filmmaking; 540 President Street, Brooklyn

“Our goal with this competition is to recognize outstanding writing achievement by

three poems; Fiction: A short story or one-act; Nonfiction: A personal or academic
essay. First-place winners in each category are awarded a prize of $1,000, second-
place winners receive $500, and third-place winners receive $250. Finalists and
winners are also eligible for undergraduate scholarships at Bennington."
“The Future Artists Program is a free, 14-week program that offers art workshops

“The Modeling the Future Challenge is a real-world competition for high school

Deadline Approaching: EPICS in IEEE Access and Abilities Competition
“EPICS in IEEE is excited to launch our fall call for proposals that will fund
applications of artificial intelligence and autonomous systems. EPICS in IEEE
proposals should address specific applications of AI in industries such as healthcare,
agriculture, education, environmental improvements, and other applications for
societal benefit. The proposal should detail how the student team will attempt to solve
an accessibility problem using engineering and technology skills. Selected teams can
win up to $10,000 to build their prototype or solution!”
Dates: Project schedule lasts until December 2025
“The TurnUp Civic Tech Challenge welcomes folks under age 26 to share their idea

Whichever extra-curricular program, internship, or community service activity a
student may participate in, they should be sure to ask their supervisor/coordinator to
write a letter of appreciation before it concludes – it is sometimes very difficult to
obtain this later on. And the more personal & detailed the letter, the better. A copy
should then be submitted to your counselor.
